The Cabinet discussed the situation arisingout of the passage of the Second Reading of theCoal Mines Bill, I;ut only by a majority of eight,in the House of Commons on Thursday, December19th.The President of the Board of Trade gave to theCabinet particulars of amendments to the Bill whichhe was drawing up to meet criticisms made in thecourse of the Parliamentary Debate under thefollowing heads:-(i) Amalgamation of collieries,(ii) Protection for cons vim ers .(iii) Added values.(iv) Time limit under legislation.After discussion the Cabinet agreed (a) That the Coal Mines Bill shouldbe proceeded with in,Parliament.(b) That the President of the Boardof Trade should frame his a-: end-ments, but should put them on thePaper before Christmas only ifthey had been fully examined and found to be satisfactory.(c) That the President of the Boardof Trade should see representa-tives of the Press the same day and make a statement to them onhis own responsibility on thelines of the Cabinet discussion,but including particulars of thegeneral scope of the amendmentshe intended to propose. ThePresident was asked to deal inparticular with the suggestion made in certain quarters thatthe Bill is a "Dear Coal Bill".(d) That the President'of the Boardof Trade should have a free handregarding further approaches fromthe Opposition Parties in Parlia-ent. PARLIAMI NTARY 2. Following the discussion referred to in thePROGRAMME.preceding Conclusions, the Cabinet had a general discussion of a preliminary character in regard totheir Parliamentary programme.The Prime Minister invited each of his colleagues,-with a view to further discussion of the questionafter the Christmas holidays, to study the King'sSpeech at the outset of the Session, and, havingregard to the limited amount of time available, toconsider which items, beyond those already intro-duced, ought to be pressed on with. He drew attention more particularly to the importance of aSlum Clearance Bill and some legislation for agriculture, such as a Marketing Bill and a rural housing Bill.Ac ong other measures on which emphasis was laidduring this discussion were:-THE HOURS BILL,A CONSUMERS' COUNCIL BILL,UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE FORAGRIC LTUxiAL LABOURERS.(previous reference:Cabinet 5Z(29), Con-clusion 5.)
